text: 1. He who knows himself as the fivefold hymn (uktha), the emblem of Prâ n a (breath), from whence all this springs 2 , he is clever. These five are the earth, air, ether, water, and fire ( g yotis). This is the self, the fivefold uktha. For from him all this springs, and into him it enters again (at the dissolution of the world). He who knows this, becomes the refuge of his friends.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 2. And to him who knows the food (object) and the feeder (subject) in that uktha, a strong son is born, and food is never wanting. Water and earth are food, for all food consists of these two. Fire and air are the feeder, for by means of them 3 man eats all food. Ether is the bowl, for all this is poured into the ether. He who knows this, becomes the bowl or support of his friends.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 3. To him who knows the food and the feeder in that uktha, a strong son is born, and food is never wanting. Herbs and trees are food, animals the feeder, for animals eat herbs and trees.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 4. Of them again those who have teeth above

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: and below, shaped after the likeness of man, are feeders, the other animals are food. Therefore these overcome the other animals, for the eater is over the food.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 5. He who knows this is over his friends.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 221:1 In this adhyâya some more qualities are explained belonging to the Mahâvrata ceremonial and the hymns employed at it, which can be meditated on as referring to Prâ n a, life.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 221:2 Because the world is the result or reward for performing a meditation on the uktha. Comm.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 221:3 The digestive fire is lighted by the air of the breath. Comm.
